body.raw:
[captioned-image src="/img/gallery/DXM.png" width="350" caption="Dextromethorphan molecule diagram." align="right" top="true" border="true" /]
[p]This article is part of an ongoing project to apply the [int-link to="/effects/"]subjective effect index[/int-link] to specific psychoactive substances in order to document their phenomenological effects in a comprehensive and formalised manner. This will initially be achieved by the [int-link to="/profiles/Josie"]site's founder[/int-link] employing her first-hand knowledge of hallucinogenic substances and the subjective effects they induce. Eventually we will establish a more refined methodology by employing a small team ingesting these substances at a range of dosages, and documenting their experiences through the use of standardized [int-link to="/reports/"]trip reports[/int-link] using our [ext-link to="https://docs.google.com/forms/u/0/d/1VdkmHgkng78fPrpqIFd7qDti5B7ml_oD8ZFiHbid8w0/edit?usp=forms_home&ths=true"]SEI form system[/ext-link]. We will then analyse this collected data in order to further detail and substantiate the effects that are induced at specific dosage ranges, their levels of intensity, style variations, and approximate frequency of occurrence.[/p]

[p]DXM is a [int-link to="/summaries/dissociatives"]dissociative hallucinogen[/int-link] within the morphinan chemical class. It is widely available for purchase at many pharmacies throughout the world in the form of cough syrup and tablets. The substance itself induces dissociative anaesthesia alongside significantly more psychedelic effects than that of other more traditional dissociatives, such as ketamine, PCP, and MXE. As this article will exclusively focus on this compound's subjective effects, if you would like to learn more about DXM's chemistry, pharmacology, history, legality, and potential dangers, then please see its PsychonautWiki article [ext-link to="https://psychonautwiki.org/wiki/DXM"]here[/ext-link].[/p]

[hr /]

[h2]Duration[/h2]

[markdown text="**Total :** 8 - 12 hours* 
**Onset :** 30 - 120 minutes* 
**Come up :** 60 - 120 minutes* 
**Peak :** 3 - 6 hours* 
**Offset :** 2 - 4 hours* 
**After effects :** 4 - 24 hours" /]
[p]It is extremely important to note that the duration listed above applies to only the majority of people as DXM is metabolised through the CYP2D6 enzyme which has significantly reduced activity in approximately 10% of the population. This means that for certain individuals, DXM may be metabolised much more slowly than average in a manner which can result in a duration of up to 18-48 hours alongside of greatly increased uncomfortable side effects such as overstimulation and itchiness. This article assumes that the person ingesting DXM has a more normally functioning CYP2D6 enzyme.[/p]

[p]The duration of DXM trips can also often be felt to be split into four separate phases which feel subjectively different from one another. The [i]first[/i] phase occurs while the user is still coming up on the substance. It typically consists of progressively more intense feelings of nausea and dissociative effects which culminate at the start of the peak with either vomiting and/or significantly reduced nausea. This nausea increases in its intensity proportional to the dosage consumed and is considerably more prevalent under the influence of DXM that comes in the form of cough syrup as opposed to pure powder or pills.[/p]

[p]The [i]second phase[/i] lasts throughout the duration of the peak and can be described as feeling close to that of a traditional dissociative with a range of disconnective effects and cognitive suppressions. However, during the offset, the effects shift into the substances third phase in a manner which feels significantly more psychedelic, with an increase in high-level geometry, dream-like internal hallucinations, introspective thought patterns, and profound feelings of increased spirituality.[/p]

[p]The final phase occurs during the day after the experience, once the user has slept. Depending on the individual's neurochemistry, it typically consists of either an afterglow or a hangover, with the afterglow feeling like an increase in energy, mania, mood elevation, and physical euphoria. This typically wears off approximately half way through the day and subsides into a general sense of sleepiness and lethargy. However, if the person is more prone to a hangover or has taken an overly heavy dosage, then they will likely experience feelings of lethargy, anxiety, inattentiveness, and mild depression. This will usually subside before the end of the day but may last multiple days in extreme cases.[/p]

[hr /]

[h2]Intensity scale[/h2]

[p]This intensity scale breaks the subjective effects of DXM into seven distinct levels, in which each tier typically contains an expanding list of effects. These effects intensity proportionally to the dosage consumed. The approximate frequency of occurrence is also listed alongside each effect. For an explanation of the terms used within this frequency measuring system, please see the article [int-link to="/articles/approximate-frequency-of-occurrence-scale"]here[/int-link]. Furthermore, it is important to note that the dosages provided here are average measurements that are comparable to recommendations made by [ext-link to="https://psychonautwiki.org/wiki/DXM"]PsychonautWiki[/ext-link] and [ext-link to="https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/dxm_dose.shtml"]Erowid[/ext-link]. The DXM dose required to reach a given range of effects seems to vary widely between individuals, depending on both body weight and neurochemistry. This variation in dosage sensitivity appears to be far more common among DXM users than almost any other hallucinogenic substance. For example, while some people may find themselves unusually sensitive to this compound, others will require a much higher dose than those recommended by this article and other reliable sources. It is therefore common for people within the psychonaut community to use [ext-link to="https://dxm.tripsit.me/"]DXM calculators[/ext-link] which predict the required dosage depending on body weight. These dosage calculators usually refer to a 5 tier plateau system that was popularised in 2002 by [ext-link to="https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml"]Erowid's DXM FAQ[/ext-link].[/p]

[p]Although the levelling system documented on this page here is approximately—although not entirely—analogous to this plateau system, it is important to keep in mind that there are many subtle differences.[/p]

[headered-textbox label="Level 1" header="Subtle" subHeader="(100 - 200 mg)" labelBackground="#AAAAAA" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]

At the lowest level, DXM frequently induces a small range of subtle [int-link to="/categories/cognitive-effects"]cognitive effects[/int-link] which may be beneficial for enhancing a person's [int-link to="/effects/empathy-affection-and-sociability-enhancement"]sociabilitity[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/stimulation"]energy levels[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/anxiety-suppression"]calmness[/int-link], and [int-link to="/effects/creativity-enhancement"]creativity[/int-link]. 

There may also be a sensation that the [int-link to="/effects/perception-of-bodily-lightness"]body feels lighter[/int-link], resulting in a sense of bounciness and ease of movement. 
However, these changes may be difficult to distinguish between that of genuine alterations and the placebo effect, unless the person is already familiar with the substance. 
This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[ext-link to="https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.3"]body feels lighter[/ext-link]". 
The specific subtle effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.

[/headered-textbox]

[markdown text="* [int-link to="/effects/anxiety-suppression"]**Anxiety suppression**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/conceptual-thinking"]**Conceptual thinking**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/creativity-enhancement"]**Creativity enhancement**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/decreased-libido"]**Increased libido**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/increased-sense-of-humor"]**Increased sense of humor**[/int-link] <sup>(uncommon)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/novelty-enhancement"]**Novelty enhancement**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/perception-of-bodily-lightness"]**Perception of bodily lightness**[/int-link] <sup>(common)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/stimulation"]**Stimulation**[/int-link] <sup>(frequent)</sup>* [int-link to="/effects/thought-acceleration"]**Thought acceleration**[/int-link] <sup>(frequent)</sup>" /]


[headered-textbox label="Level 2" header="Mild" subHeader="(200 - 400 mg)" labelBackground="#a4a3a3" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]

At this level, the effects of DXM can be generally described as a subtle dulling of the senses and a vague feeling of [int-link to="/effects/physical-disconnection"]physical detachment[/int-link] from the external environment, which is accompanied by a distinct sense of [int-link to="/effects/cognitive-euphoria"]mood elevation[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/empathy-affection-and-sociability-enhancement"]physical detachment[/int-link], and [int-link to="/effects/stimulation"]stimulation[/int-link]. 

The [int-link to="/effects/empathy-affection-and-sociability-enhancement"]sociability enhancement[/int-link] experienced at this dosage range is mildly entactogenic and can be described as forcibly induced feelings of love, empathy, and talkativeness. Although it is comparable in its style to the entactogenia induced by substances such as MDMA, it is much subtler in its intensity and forcefulness in a manner which is similar to that of 2C-B. 

However, this effect is usually only present at these lower levels of intensity as when the dosage is increased, it eventually gives way to more typical dissociative effects.These effects are accompanied by mild but pleasurable spontaneous tactile sensations which are commonly referred to as a "body high." The specific details of which can be described through its [int-link to="/effects/spontaneous-tactile-sensations#style-variations"]style variations[/int-link] as *moving in motion, sporadic in consistency, sharp in sensation, euphoric in pleasurableness, and often localised in its position to the hands, feet, or head*.At this point, the user may have to pay direct attention to the effects of the substance for them to be recognisable, or they may be noticeable but will not necessarily demand the user's attention.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[second plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.4)".  

The specific subtle effects that generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.

[/headered-textbox]

[headered-textbox label="Level 3" header="Moderate" subHeader="(400 - 700 mg)" labelBackground="#9e9d9c" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]At this level, the environment starts to feel physically further away in distance and increasingly disconnected from a person’s sensory perception. 

Partially blurred and double vision sets in, and anaesthetic-like effects such as [int-link to="/effects/tactile-suppression"]tactile numbness[/int-link] begin to take place. Other physical faculties such as [int-link to="/effects/motor-control-loss"]motor control, coordination, and balance[/int-link] become somewhat suppressed in a manner that is partially compensated for by a feeling of the body being in a state of "autopilot". Interestingly enough, this suppression of motor control is unique in its style as it frequently results in users moving around in a [int-link to="/effects/gait-alteration"]robotic and mechanical-like gait[/int-link] that does not seem to present itself under the influence of other dissociative substances. 

Within the DXM community, this is colloquially referred to as a "robo walk".These physical effects are also accompanied by a pronounced feeling of [int-link to="/effects/sedation"]bodily sedation[/int-link] that begins to overtake the [int-link to="/effects/stimulation"]stimulation[/int-link] that is felt at lower dosages, and is accompanied by other [int-link to="/categories/cognitive-suppressions"]cognitive suppressions[/int-link] such as [int-link to="/effects/thought-deceleration"]thought deceleration[/int-link]. However, this sedation should not be confused with a sense of actual [int-link to="/effects/sleepiness"]sleepiness[/int-link] as it is more comparable to feeling extremely heavy and unable to move one's body. Alongside of this, the user will likely feel a sense of persistent [int-link to="/effects/dry-mouth"]dry mouth[/int-link] or [int-link to="/effects/dehydration"]mild dehydration[/int-link] that often requires periodic sipping of water to keep it from reaching significant levels of discomfort.Various adverse effects such as itching and rashes may also occur at this dosage range and above. 

Although it is uncommon, it is worth noting that a certain percentage of people seem to experience [int-link to="/effects/itchiness"]itchiness[/int-link] on DXM that is comparable to that which occurs on opioids such morphine, kratom, and heroin. This is colloquially referred to as a "robo itch" within the DXM community and is likely a result of histamine release. In terms of auditory perception, the clarity of sound itself may seem as if it has become [int-link to="/effects/auditory-suppression"]vague, muffled, and distant[/int-link]. Nonetheless, one's sense of [int-link to="/effects/increased-music-appreciation"]music appreciation[/int-link] will have profoundly increased.  Regarding visual effects, some inconsistent and brief distortions may also occur spontaneously during dissociative experiences. 

These distortions can include alterations in perceived distances between objects, visual segmentation of one's vision into glitch-like [int-link to="/effects/environmental-cubism"]cubes[/int-link] or [int-link to="/effects/scenery-slicing"]slices[/int-link], and changes to the perceived size of one's body or the environment.During this level, if one allows themselves to relax while closing their eyes, they may find that they are fleetingly and partially drifting off into a [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=holes-spaces-voids"]darkened hallucinatory void[/int-link] filled with vague [int-link to="/effects/geometry"]psychedelic geometry[/int-link] alongside simplistic [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=structures"]shapes, forms, and structures[/int-link]. 

This is usually a very brief and indistinct experience, which can quickly be interrupted by external stimuli such as noises or other distractions.With DXM in particular, it is worth noting that its [int-link to="/effects/geometry"]geometry[/int-link] is typically much more distinct, colourful, pronounced, and psychedelic-esque in comparison to that of other more commonly used dissociatives. Although it does not usually extend beyond level 5 geometry and is not entirely on par with a typical psychedelic in terms of complexity, it can often come very close in terms of its intensity, colour palette, and vividness. This effect will typically begin to manifest at this level subtly, and its intensity increases proportional to the dosage consumed. It can be comprehensively described through its [int-link to="/effects/geometry#style-variations"]style variations[/int-link] as *intricate in complexity, algorithmic in style, unstructured in organization, brightly lit in lighting, multicoloured in scheme, glossy in shading, soft in edges, small in size, slow in speed, smooth in motion, equal in rounded and angular corners, immersive in-depth and consistent in intensity*.There is also a distinct possibility that the user may experience stereotypical psychedelic drifting which causes the environment to appear to warp, morph, bend, and flow. However, although this effect is more common on DXM in comparison to that of other more common dissociatives, it is still substantially less common in comparison to that of a traditional psychedelic. The [int-link to="/effects/drifting#style-variations"]style variations of this drifting[/int-link] are simple in complexity, slow-moving, smooth in perceived framerate, constant throughout, and unrealistic in its appearance.Depending on the person's level of experience with this substance, these effects can be allowed to occupy a predominant role within the person's perception, or they may be partially ignored and made somewhat secondary to other chosen activities.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[third plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.7)". The specific distinct effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.[/headered-textbox][int-link regulation suppression**[/int-link] <sup>(uncommon)</sup>" /][headered-textbox label="Level 4" header="Strong" subHeader="(700 - 800 mg)" labelBackground="#8f8e8d" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]At this level, the [int-link to="/categories/disconnective-effects"]sensory and cognitive disconnection[/int-link] has begun to completely block out the user's perception of the external environment. It is here where the person may find themselves undergoing an out-of-body experience as they float in a variety of directions and orientations through a "[int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=holes-spaces-voids"]dissociative hole[/int-link]", which can be described as an expansive darkened void containing a wide array of [int-link to="/effects/internal-hallucination"]internal hallucinations[/int-link] and [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=structures"]structures[/int-link]. These structures are usually formed from solid materials which can take the form of any shape. Common examples include *vast and monolithic pillars, columns, walls, tunnels, blocks, buildings, slides, monuments, wheels, pyramids, caverns, and a variety of abstract or fractal shapes*. The internal hallucinations that occur at this level will usually consist of vivid, ever-changing dream-like scenes and imagery. They can be comprehensively described through their [int-link to="/effects/internal-hallucination#style-variations"]style variations[/int-link] as a combination of *lucid and delirious in awareness, fixed in style, primarily novel experiences over everyday or biographical content, autonomous in interactivity, and with a combination of both realistic and geometry based visual styles*.Although they are substantially less common than [int-link to="/effects/internal-hallucination"]internal hallucinations[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/external-hallucination"]external hallucinations[/int-link] can also occasionally occur at heavy dosages of DXM. These are typically deliriant-like in nature and consist of solid hallucinations of objects or people blending seamlessly into the external environment. The most common theme seems to be the hallucination of conversing with other people in the environment who were not actually present throughout the trip. However, it is important to note that despite this effect being more common under the influence of DXM in comparison to that of other dissociatives, it is still quite rare and may never be experienced even by regular users.Alongside these disconnective hallucinatory effects, the user may experience feelings of altered cognition that feel as if they direct one's thought stream towards topics of [int-link to="/effects/introspection"]introspection[/int-link], an [int-link to="/effects/analysis-enhancement"]analysis of the details of their life[/int-link], and a general sense of [int-link to="/effects/spirituality-enhancement"]spiritual or philosophical contemplation[/int-link].This is the level at which the effects become powerful enough to render the person undergoing them as [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=holes-spaces-voids"]incapable of functioning, interacting normally, or thinking in a sober manner[/int-link]. At this level, the effects of the substance are apparent and can no longer be ignored in any capacity, leaving the user entirely engaged in the experience whether they wish to be or not. In terms of how this looks from an outsiders perspective, the person will usually appear to be either heavily sedated or almost entirely unconscious.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to the lower end of a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[fourth plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.7)". The specific distinct effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.[/headered-textbox][int-link subHeader="(800 - 900 mg)" labelBackground="#7a7a79" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]At this level, the dissociation and detachment from the person's senses and consciousness has become intense enough for their [int-link to="/effects/memory-suppression"]long-term memory[/int-link] and [int-link to="/effects/ego-death"]feeling of selfhood[/int-link] to cease functioning. This leads into a state which is commonly referred to as "[int-link to="/effects/ego-death"]ego death[/int-link]" due to the way in which the person completely loses their ability to recall and comprehend their own sense of identity.This state of ego loss is accompanied by extremely [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=holes-spaces-voids"]vivid hallucinatory voids[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=structures"]structures[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/geometry"]geometric forms[/int-link], sensory disconnection, [int-link to="/effects/internal-hallucination"]internal hallucinations[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/delusion"]delusions[/int-link], and occasionally life-changing spiritual or [int-link to="/categories/transpersonal-states"]transpersonal experiences[/int-link].  It is worth noting that during this dosage range, feelings of sudden [int-link to="/effects/anxiety"]anxiety[/int-link], panic, or even an impending sense of doom can spontaneously occur at any point throughout the trip for no discernible reason. Although this is relatively uncommon, it can occur regardless of the users level of experience and can even suddenly manifest during the offset of the drug when the person has begun to feel almost entirely sober. This experience typically lasts any where from thirty minutes to a couple of hours, and seems more likely to manifest for people who use this substance on a regular basis.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to the upper end of a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[fourth plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.7)". The specific distinct effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.[/headered-textbox][int-link to="/effects/vibrating-vision"]**Vibrating vision**[/int-link] <sup>(uncommon)</sup>" /][headered-textbox label="Level 6" header="Extreme" subHeader="(900 - 1200 mg)" labelBackground="#6d6d6c" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]The highest level of detachment occurs when a person [int-link to="/effects/visual-disconnection?s=holes-spaces-voids"]loses all sensory awareness[/int-link] and semblance of normal cognitive functioning. This renders the person unconscious and consistently leaves extended gaps in a person’s memory with large periods of [int-link to="/effects/amnesia"]amnesia[/int-link] which are generally impossible to recall once the experience is over. It is at this level of dissociation that other dissociative substances such as ketamine are used in medical procedures for their anaesthetic effects.At this dosage range, the person will experience the effects typically associated with the previously described level during the onset and offset of their trip. During the peak, however, they will black out and become unconscious for a prolonged period of time that is directly proportional to the dosage consumed.Although this extreme dissociative state may be attractive to certain individuals, it is worth noting that this level of intensity is not only potentially dangerous but also less therapeutic and exploratory than the previous levels. With DXM in particular, it is said by sites such as [Erowid](https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/dxm_dose.shtml) that dosages between 2,500 mg and 20,000 mg are capable of resulting in death. However, this seems unusually high to me, and I would not personally be surprised if dosages closer to 1000mg were capable of causing a fatal overdose within certain individuals that have either a lower body weight or a higher sensitivity.[/headered-textbox][headered-textbox label="Level 7" header="Prolonged" labelBackground="#555554" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]This state of DXM is not necessarily the highest level of the substances potential intensity but is qualitatively different from that of the previously listed levels. This state is induced by taking successive doses of DXM over several hours, instead of a single dose. It is reported to intensify many aspects of the DXM experience, and often produces more vivid and disorientating [int-link to="/effects/external-hallucination"]external hallucinations[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/autonomous-entity"]autonomous entity[/int-link] contact, [int-link to="/effects/delirium"]delirium[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/anxiety"]anxiety[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/delusion"]delusions[/int-link], [int-link to="/effects/psychosis"]psychosis[/int-link] and many other extremely unpleasant side effects. Within the DXM community it is colloquially referred to as "plateau sigma" and was originally described in Erowid's 2002 [DXM FAQ](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.9). It is usually achieved using the following technique:1. Take a weak "second plateau" dosage at approximately 200-400 mg. It is recommended to do this earlier in the day due to the lengthiness of this process, as sleep deprivation or fatigue can negatively impact the experience.2. After approximately three hours (or about one hour after the peak) take another weak "second plateau" dosage.3. After another three hours (or about one hour after the second peak) take either a strong "second plateau" or a weak "third plateau" dosage at approximately 400-600mg.4. During the offset of this third dosage, the user may find themselves experiencing "plateau sigma" instead of slowly returning to baseline.However, it is important to note that within the DXM community, this experience is widely considered extremely unpleasant and potentially dangerous. There are seemingly very few cases of people who enjoy this state of mind. Because of these factors, it is universally advised that people avoid experimenting with it altogether.[/headered-textbox]

[markdown text="### Experience reports" /]Anecdotal reports which describe the effects of this compound within our experience index include:[int-link to="/reports/re-discovering-dxm"]markdown text="- [**Re-discovering DXM**[/int-link] by [int-link to="/profiles/Josie"]*Josie Kins*[/int-link]- [int-link to="/reports/heavy-dose-of-cough-syrup"]**Heavy dose of cough syrup**[/int-link] by *Gabriel*" /]

[h2]Personal commentary[/h2]
[quote author="Josie Kins" profile="Josie"]In my opinion, DXM is tragically overlooked and underrated by the mainstream psychonaut community. It is easily one of my favourite hallucinogens, as for me personally, it induces therapeutic introspection alongside profound feelings of spirituality enhancement in a manner that is more consistent than almost any of the other 120+ substances which I am experienced with. In fact, the only other hallucinogenic substance which is as consistently equal to me in this regard is ayahuasca.However, it is worth noting that I very much seem to be an outlier when it comes this. Over the years I have witnessed many other people under the influence of DXM, and while they usually hold it in high regard, only a small fraction of them seem to benefit from its effects to quite the same extent that I do. However, in an attempt to diminish my bias as much as possible, I have been sure to take this into account within the documentation above.I suspect the reason that I benefit from DXM so much stems from a combination of having a compatible physiology, as well the way in which its unique effect profile results in a trip which is seemingly 75% dissociative and 25% psychedelic — allowing me to simultaneously experience the positive aspects of both hallucinogenic classes, all within a single compound. I usually find that the first two-thirds of the experience is primarily dissociative in its effects with the last third being primarily psychedelic, with a headspace that also changes into something reminiscent of tryptamines. It's during this latter phase in which I typically undergo the aforementioned feelings of therapeutic introspection combined with a sense of profound and contemplative spiritual reverence towards my place within this universe.For many people, DXM seems to have a reputation of being a "kiddie drug" that presumably stems from a number of factors. For example, its ease of availability results in young teenagers commonly using or abusing this substance when they cannot access anything else. In addition to this, approximately 10% of users cannot metabolise it correctly which likely results in them reporting disproportionately adverse side effects that people fail to realise will not occur for the majority of the population. It is also commonly taken in the form of cough syrup which many people are understandably apprehensive about ingesting while remaining unaware that is also commonly available in other forms. Despite this reputation, however, DXM is an incredibly powerful hallucinogen that can potentially offer as much depth to it as any of the other classical dissociatives or hallucinogens. It's because of this that I would highly recommend any budding psychonaut to consider either revisiting this compound or giving it an honest try if they have yet to do so.[/quote]

Eventually we will establish a more refined methodology by employing a small team ingesting these substances at a range of dosages, and documenting their experiences through the use of standardized

children: within the morphinan chemical class. It is widely available for purchase at many pharmacies throughout the world in the form of cough syrup and tablets. The substance itself induces dissociative anaesthesia alongside significantly more psychedelic effects than that of other more traditional dissociatives, such as ketamine, PCP, and MXE. As this article will exclusively focus on this compound's subjective effects, if you would like to learn more about DXM's chemistry, pharmacology, history, legality, and potential dangers, then please see its PsychonautWiki article

properties.text:
**Total :** 8 - 12 hours* 
**Onset :** 30 - 120 minutes* 
**Come up :** 60 - 120 minutes* 
**Peak :** 3 - 6 hours* 
**Offset :** 2 - 4 hours* 
**After effects :** 4 - 24 hours

parsed.name: p
children: It is extremely important to note that the duration listed above applies to only the majority of people as DXM is metabolised through the CYP2D6 enzyme which has significantly reduced activity in approximately 10% of the population. This means that for certain individuals, DXM may be metabolised much more slowly than average in a manner which can result in a duration of up to 18-48 hours alongside of greatly increased uncomfortable side effects such as overstimulation and itchiness. This article assumes that the person ingesting DXM has a more normally functioning CYP2D6 enzyme.

parsed.name: p
children: The duration of DXM trips can also often be felt to be split into four separate phases which feel subjectively different from one another. The

phase occurs while the user is still coming up on the substance. It typically consists of progressively more intense feelings of nausea and dissociative effects which culminate at the start of the peak with either vomiting and/or significantly reduced nausea. This nausea increases in its intensity proportional to the dosage consumed and is considerably more prevalent under the influence of DXM that comes in the form of cough syrup as opposed to pure powder or pills.

parsed.name: p
children: lasts throughout the duration of the peak and can be described as feeling close to that of a traditional dissociative with a range of disconnective effects and cognitive suppressions. However, during the offset, the effects shift into the substances third phase in a manner which feels significantly more psychedelic, with an increase in high-level geometry, dream-like internal hallucinations, introspective thought patterns, and profound feelings of increased spirituality.

parsed.name: p
children: The final phase occurs during the day after the experience, once the user has slept. Depending on the individual's neurochemistry, it typically consists of either an afterglow or a hangover, with the afterglow feeling like an increase in energy, mania, mood elevation, and physical euphoria. This typically wears off approximately half way through the day and subsides into a general sense of sleepiness and lethargy. However, if the person is more prone to a hangover or has taken an overly heavy dosage, then they will likely experience feelings of lethargy, anxiety, inattentiveness, and mild depression. This will usually subside before the end of the day but may last multiple days in extreme cases.

parsed.name: p
children: This intensity scale breaks the subjective effects of DXM into seven distinct levels, in which each tier typically contains an expanding list of effects. These effects intensity proportionally to the dosage consumed. The approximate frequency of occurrence is also listed alongside each effect. For an explanation of the terms used within this frequency measuring system, please see the article
. Furthermore, it is important to note that the dosages provided here are average measurements that are comparable to recommendations made by

. The DXM dose required to reach a given range of effects seems to vary widely between individuals, depending on both body weight and neurochemistry. This variation in dosage sensitivity appears to be far more common among DXM users than almost any other hallucinogenic substance. For example, while some people may find themselves unusually sensitive to this compound, others will require a much higher dose than those recommended by this article and other reliable sources. It is therefore common for people within the psychonaut community to use
which predict the required dosage depending on body weight. These dosage calculators usually refer to a 5 tier plateau system that was popularised in 2002 by

that does not seem to present itself under the influence of other dissociative substances. 

Within the DXM community, this is colloquially referred to as a "robo walk".These physical effects are also accompanied by a pronounced feeling of

Although it is uncommon, it is worth noting that a certain percentage of people seem to experience

on DXM that is comparable to that which occurs on opioids such morphine, kratom, and heroin. This is colloquially referred to as a "robo itch" within the DXM community and is likely a result of histamine release. In terms of auditory perception, the clarity of sound itself may seem as if it has become

will have profoundly increased.  Regarding visual effects, some inconsistent and brief distortions may also occur spontaneously during dissociative experiences. 

These distortions can include alterations in perceived distances between objects, visual segmentation of one's vision into glitch-like

, and changes to the perceived size of one's body or the environment.During this level, if one allows themselves to relax while closing their eyes, they may find that they are fleetingly and partially drifting off into a

This is usually a very brief and indistinct experience, which can quickly be interrupted by external stimuli such as noises or other distractions.With DXM in particular, it is worth noting that its

is typically much more distinct, colourful, pronounced, and psychedelic-esque in comparison to that of other more commonly used dissociatives. Although it does not usually extend beyond level 5 geometry and is not entirely on par with a typical psychedelic in terms of complexity, it can often come very close in terms of its intensity, colour palette, and vividness. This effect will typically begin to manifest at this level subtly, and its intensity increases proportional to the dosage consumed. It can be comprehensively described through its

as *intricate in complexity, algorithmic in style, unstructured in organization, brightly lit in lighting, multicoloured in scheme, glossy in shading, soft in edges, small in size, slow in speed, smooth in motion, equal in rounded and angular corners, immersive in-depth and consistent in intensity*.There is also a distinct possibility that the user may experience stereotypical psychedelic drifting which causes the environment to appear to warp, morph, bend, and flow. However, although this effect is more common on DXM in comparison to that of other more common dissociatives, it is still substantially less common in comparison to that of a traditional psychedelic. are simple in complexity, slow-moving, smooth in perceived framerate, constant throughout, and unrealistic in its appearance.Depending on the person's level of experience with this substance, these effects can be allowed to occupy a predominant role within the person's perception, or they may be partially ignored and made somewhat secondary to other chosen activities.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[third plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.7)". These are typically deliriant-like in nature and consist of solid hallucinations of objects or people blending seamlessly into the external environment. .  It is worth noting that during this dosage range, feelings of sudden

, panic, or even an impending sense of doom can spontaneously occur at any point throughout the trip for no discernible reason. Although this is relatively uncommon, it can occur regardless of the users level of experience and can even suddenly manifest during the offset of the drug when the person has begun to feel almost entirely sober. This experience typically lasts any where from thirty minutes to a couple of hours, and seems more likely to manifest for people who use this substance on a regular basis.This level of DXM intensity is roughly analogous to the upper end of a state which is colloquially referred to as the "[fourth plateau](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.7)". The specific distinct effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, listed below.

parsed.name: headered-textbox
children: The highest level of detachment occurs when a person
and semblance of normal cognitive functioning. This renders the person unconscious and consistently leaves extended gaps in a person’s memory with large periods of

which are generally impossible to recall once the experience is over. It is at this level of dissociation that other dissociative substances such as ketamine are used in medical procedures for their anaesthetic effects.At this dosage range, the person will experience the effects typically associated with the previously described level during the onset and offset of their trip. During the peak, however, they will black out and become unconscious for a prolonged period of time that is directly proportional to the dosage consumed.Although this extreme dissociative state may be attractive to certain individuals, it is worth noting that this level of intensity is not only potentially dangerous but also less therapeutic and exploratory than the previous levels. With DXM in particular, it is said by sites such as [Erowid](https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/dxm_dose.shtml) that dosages between 2,500 mg and 20,000 mg are capable of resulting in death. However, this seems unusually high to me, and I would not personally be surprised if dosages closer to 1000mg were capable of causing a fatal overdose within certain individuals that have either a lower body weight or a higher sensitivity.

parsed.name: headered-textbox
children: This state of DXM is not necessarily the highest level of the substances potential intensity but is qualitatively different from that of the previously listed levels. This state is induced by taking successive doses of DXM over several hours, instead of a single dose. It is reported to intensify many aspects of the DXM experience, and often produces more vivid and disorientating

and many other extremely unpleasant side effects. Within the DXM community it is colloquially referred to as "plateau sigma" and was originally described in Erowid's 2002 [DXM FAQ](https://erowid.org/chemicals/dxm/faq/dxm_experience.shtml#toc.5.9). It is usually achieved using the following technique:1. Take a weak "second plateau" dosage at approximately 200-400 mg. It is recommended to do this earlier in the day due to the lengthiness of this process, as sleep deprivation or fatigue can negatively impact the experience.2. After approximately three hours (or about one hour after the peak) take another weak "second plateau" dosage.3. After another three hours (or about one hour after the second peak) take either a strong "second plateau" or a weak "third plateau" dosage at approximately 400-600mg.4. During the offset of this third dosage, the user may find themselves experiencing "plateau sigma" instead of slowly returning to baseline.However, it is important to note that within the DXM community, this experience is widely considered extremely unpleasant and potentially dangerous. There are seemingly very few cases of people who enjoy this state of mind. Because of these factors, it is universally advised that people avoid experimenting with it altogether.

parsed: Anecdotal reports which describe the effects of this compound within our experience index include:

parsed.name: quote
children: In my opinion, DXM is tragically overlooked and underrated by the mainstream psychonaut community. It is easily one of my favourite hallucinogens, as for me personally, it induces therapeutic introspection alongside profound feelings of spirituality enhancement in a manner that is more consistent than almost any of the other 120+ substances which I am experienced with. In fact, the only other hallucinogenic substance which is as consistently equal to me in this regard is ayahuasca.However, it is worth noting that I very much seem to be an outlier when it comes this. Over the years I have witnessed many other people under the influence of DXM, and while they usually hold it in high regard, only a small fraction of them seem to benefit from its effects to quite the same extent that I do. However, in an attempt to diminish my bias as much as possible, I have been sure to take this into account within the documentation above.I suspect the reason that I benefit from DXM so much stems from a combination of having a compatible physiology, as well the way in which its unique effect profile results in a trip which is seemingly 75% dissociative and 25% psychedelic — allowing me to simultaneously experience the positive aspects of both hallucinogenic classes, all within a single compound. I usually find that the first two-thirds of the experience is primarily dissociative in its effects with the last third being primarily psychedelic, with a headspace that also changes into something reminiscent of tryptamines. It's during this latter phase in which I typically undergo the aforementioned feelings of therapeutic introspection combined with a sense of profound and contemplative spiritual reverence towards my place within this universe.For many people, DXM seems to have a reputation of being a "kiddie drug" that presumably stems from a number of factors. For example, its ease of availability results in young teenagers commonly using or abusing this substance when they cannot access anything else. In addition to this, approximately 10% of users cannot metabolise it correctly which likely results in them reporting disproportionately adverse side effects that people fail to realise will not occur for the majority of the population. It is also commonly taken in the form of cough syrup which many people are understandably apprehensive about ingesting while remaining unaware that is also commonly available in other forms. Despite this reputation, however, DXM is an incredibly powerful hallucinogen that can potentially offer as much depth to it as any of the other classical dissociatives or hallucinogens. It's because of this that I would highly recommend any budding psychonaut to consider either revisiting this compound or giving it an honest try if they have yet to do so.

body.raw:
[p]A [b]heart opening[/b] can be defined as the experience of the function of one or more specific receptor sets or “mental organs” coming into the forefront of a person’s subjective perception, through the use of psychoactive compounds. The intensity of this experience is proportional to the extent at which the mental organs associated receptor sets are being modulated, ranging from subtle in their presence to overwhelming and impossible to ignore.[/p]

[p]Depending on the mental organ which is being manifested into consciousness, a variety of differing arrays of subjective effects may present themselves. These are listed and described in a comprehensive level of detail below.[/p]
[hr opacity="0.5" /]
[columns]
  [column]

[p]“[i]Language, logic, reason, concepts, thought, patterns in nature[/i]”[/p]
[p]POTENTIALLY ASSOCIATED SUBJECTIVE EFFECTS[/p]

[/headered-textbox]

[headered-textbox label="H1" header="Histamine H1 receptor" labelBackground="#878786" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]
[p]HYPOTHESIZED FUNCTION[/p]

parsed.name: p
children: For the countless millennia that psychoactive substances have been present in human civilisation, there has not been an established, universally applicable lexicon for articulating experiences of altered states of consciousness. The absence of such terminology has limited our ability to fully understand our own experiences and made discussion and research in this domain difficult. People who have noticed this absence have been driven to volunteer countless hours of their free time to document their experiences and coin, define, and categorize terms, ultimately culminating in the Subjective Effect Index.

parsed.name: p
children: Effect Index is the website that hosts the

(SEI), a database of 233 effect descriptions that strives to serve as a comprehensive map of all potential experiences that can occur under the influence of any class of psychoactive compound, particularly hallucinogens. The existing SEI has been increasingly used to facilitate discussion within online psychedelic spaces since around 2012. However, it has not yet reached a level of completeness and polish that would allow it to serve as a universal terminology set. By improving and completing the SEI, we intend to create a tool that will improve our collective ability to research altered states of consciousness and greatly enhance the academic, clinical, therapeutic, personal, and cultural relevance of psychoactive compounds.

parsed.name: p
children: , a Y Combinator startup, I am leading a project to develop a new version of the SEI with unparalleled comprehensiveness and academic rigor. Prominent scientific researchers such as
are serving as advisors throughout the index's development, and it will be published as a publicly available open source research paper.

parsed.name: p
children: This project will greatly improve the overarching organisational structure of the Index and more than double the number of distinct defined effects. It will incorporate a comprehensive literature review of other rudimentary altered state of consciousness ontologies, such as psychometric tools and informal classification systems found within books and online resources. We intend for this project to be fully open source so that it can become a ubiquitous resource analogous to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, providing a defined common lexicon so that researchers and laypeople alike can discuss altered states of consciousness in a succinct yet meaningful way.

parsed.name: p
children: Thanks to my employers, the creation of this particular aspect of the project is already underway. However, new funding will be needed to integrate the improved SEI into the Effect Index website and empower the Subjective Effect Documentation community to continue improving the index in our ever-evolving world. This document details what we still need to bring Effect Index to its full potential as a global source of subjective effect knowledge and discovery.

children.name: p
children: My biggest priority for this project right now is improving the infrastructure behind our website. The existing website has evolved over time through the generous contributions of multiple community volunteers, but it is presently not able to accommodate any significant changes to the overall structure of the content. While we have an excellent starting point, there are a number of important features and improvements that will need to be implemented to turn this project into a platform capable of serving as a dedicated community resource for establishing, showcasing, and progressing the field of Subjective Effect Documentation.

children.name: p
children: To maintain and implement improvements to the website, I would need to contract with a single freelance web developer, preferably on a long-term basis. My first choice for this role is a specific prominent community member who is highly capable, passionate about the project's goals, has an in-depth understanding of this project, is familiar with the website's backend code, and has been helping us work on it for a number of years.

children.name: p
children: For in-depth details on each aspect of this, feel free to look at our spreadsheet
. Otherwise, we have included a summarised list of our specific goals below.

children.name: li
children: Better, more customizable user profiles would facilitate writers, artists, replicators, and other people involved in our project to showcase their contributions and general online presence, therefore encouraging higher quality community contributions. We would like to implement:

children.name: li
children: A way to change the order of replications on user pages so that they are better suited for use as portfolios.

children.name: li
children: A way to better manage the categories of user pages, and the order of the users in them.

children.name: li
children: Simplified trip report submission to our report index. Reports would then undergo moderation and manual approval before being integrated into the Subjective Effect Index via the effect tagging process.

children.name: li
children: Upgrading the user interface to allow direct upload of images, videos, gifs, and audio files without resorting to an external FTP client. This would allow replicators and visionary artists to submit their own content easily to relevant effect pages and prevent changes in third-party services from disabling community assets.

children.name: li
children: Upgrading the trip report editor to fix numerous issues to make writing trip reports easier, as well as making trip reports easier for machine learning to process and reliably analyze. These changes include the input fields needing to be more strict with the values they accept, as well as converting between units for the user. The medications list should also be a separate list of meds and dosages, similar to how the substances box works. A more consistent time format would help with readability and ML processing. The editor should also strip whitespace around input fields.

children.name: li
children: A live preview for the VCode editor would be immensely helpful, especially for large content and formatting-dense articles.

children.name: li
children: These changes would take an estimated 190 hours to add (~$5130 USD).

children.name: li
children: To remain a relevant resource, the website should be upgraded to accommodate the following:

children.name: li
children: The newest edition of the Subjective Effect Index is being developed under Josie Kins’ work with Mind State Design Labs, and we should have the website fully prepared for the new effects and general overarching structure of the ontology by the time it is published and available to the public.

children.name: li
children: A directory of other Altered State of Consciousness Ontologies, with direct comparison to the Subjective Index. This will essentially be a user-facing showcase of the literature review that Josikinz is already working on with Mind State Design Labs.

children.name: li
children: These changes would take an estimated 180 hours to add (~$4860 USD).

children.name: li
children: Ideally as many pages outside of effects, articles, etc, should be editable within the UI of the website to the maximum extent that is practically possible. This will take inspiration from the way in which MediaWiki allows people to do much the same thing.

children.name: li
children:
We’ll need to make embeddable vcode components for a wider array of site features: tabs, read more button, tabs for viewing multiple versions of an article or article section
allow creation / editing of arbitrary pages with vcode

children.name: li
children: changing an article's icon in the web editor

children.name: li
children: We need version control for articles, much like with MediaWiki. This would allow us to track edits and revert changes more easily. Something which is essential for giving people more editor privileges.

children.name: li
children: These changes would take an estimated 160 hours to add (~$4320 USD).

children.name: li
children: A function for redirecting effects to other effects or webpages, so you create an effect that essentially serves an alternative title which people may search for. (~10h / $270)

children.name: li
children: Implement timestamps into the error log.

children.name: li
children: Automatic citation generation in a set format would make managing citations easier, as well as preferring DOIs. (~20h / $540)

children.name: li
children: Some things such as the “project” tab could have a scrolling TOC on the side? Discuss. (~30h / $810)

children.name: li
children: The “About Us” button on the page only displays after hitting “read more”. Most people probably won’t click “read more”. This is a small thing but should absolutely be fixed.

children.name: li
children: Implementing analytics to see what pages people interact with / how they interact with them (eg, what elements are clicked the most?) would be helpful when designing articles to see which elements convey information better, and so on. (~50h / $1350)

children.name: li
children: A discord bot to post updates / help manage the EI (eg, when someone submits a new trip report).  (~20h / $540)

children.name: li
children: The main page should be overhauled with new information and content, as well as phrasing such as “Hallucinogenic substance classes” being updated to use modern language. (~15h / $405)

children.name: li
children: A way to search through all articles / vcode components for text, to aide in updating content and fixing references to broken components. (~30h / $810)

children.name: li
children: Proper error handling and status codes from the API, instead of returning 500 for everything. (~30h / $810)

children.name: li
children: Embeddable gif support in the image viewer. (~15h / $405)

children.name: li
children: Articles that were published before the publish date system was added are missing a publish date. Adding a box to manually enter a date would be ideal. (~5h / $135)

children.name: li
children: We would like to implement various goals in order to make the creation and editing of content on the Effect Index easier and faster for editors.

children.name: li
children: Article formatting templates, to make creating standardised articles easier. (~15h / $675)

children.name: li
children: Fixing bugs and issues with the editor, such as visual issues with regards to account permissions. (~11h / $297)

children.name: li
children: A live preview for the VCode editor, and showing the article side-by-side instead of a tabbed view would make editing formatting easier.

children.name: li
children: A component for showing substance durations and dosages would be nice to have, when referencing a specific substance.

children.name: li
children: Inline citation links would be great (similar to mediawiki). The current css for them should also be more aesthetically pleasing. Currently the citations are too big and with too much space around them. (~30h / $810)

children.name: li
children: Overhaul the replication gallery. I would prefer to have not just the option for slideshows, but collections of tiled thumbnails for a more presentable showcasing. (~60h / $1620)

children.name: li
children: Tickboxes for managing profile roles, and managing effect tags rather than freestanding boxes would make site management easier. (~11h / $297)

parsed.name: p
children: Depending on the number of features we are implementing and at an hourly rate of $27, we estimate that this platform overhaul would cost $30,000 to fully implement. Furthermore, once implemented it would directly contribute to the Phenomenology, Practise, and Psychedelic Projects of the EPRC.

parsed.name: p
children: This project is ethically driven as a means of maximizing harm reduction and empowering people to make informed choices, for the benefit of the global community. So if you're passionate about the field of psychedelic and general phenomenological research, the potential for formalized Subjective Effect Documentation as a legitimate field of study, and the need for a truly comprehensive, universally applicable map of substance and other practice-induced altered states of consciousness, then please consider donating to our fundraising campaign.

parsed.name: p
children: Every little helps and will go directly to the cause, thank you in advance.

body.raw:
[youtube-embed src="Q4QLxpLdSrA" title="Fundraising Campaign" /][hr /]

[p]For the countless millennia that psychoactive substances have been present in human civilisation, there has not been an established, universally applicable lexicon for articulating experiences of altered states of consciousness. The absence of such terminology has limited our ability to fully understand our own experiences and made discussion and research in this domain difficult. People who have noticed this absence have been driven to volunteer countless hours of their free time to document their experiences and coin, define, and categorize terms, ultimately culminating in the Subjective Effect Index.[/p] 

[p]Effect Index is the website that hosts the [ext-link to="https://www.effectindex.com/effects"]Subjective Effect Index[/ext-link] (SEI), a database of 233 effect descriptions that strives to serve as a comprehensive map of all potential experiences that can occur under the influence of any class of psychoactive compound, particularly hallucinogens. The existing SEI has been increasingly used to facilitate discussion within online psychedelic spaces since around 2012. However, it has not yet reached a level of completeness and polish that would allow it to serve as a universal terminology set. By improving and completing the SEI, we intend to create a tool that will improve our collective ability to research altered states of consciousness and greatly enhance the academic, clinical, therapeutic, personal, and cultural relevance of psychoactive compounds.[/p]

[p]Under the employment of [ext-link to="https://www.mindstate.design/"]Mindstate Design Labs[/ext-link], a Y Combinator startup, I am leading a project to develop a new version of the SEI with unparalleled comprehensiveness and academic rigor. Prominent scientific researchers such as [ext-link to="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_S._Ray"]Thomas S. Ray[/ext-link], [ext-link to="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_B._Newberg"]Andrew B. Newburg[/ext-link], and to a lesser extent [ext-link to="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/people/r.carhart-harris"]Robin Carhart-Harris [/ext-link] are serving as advisors throughout the index's development, and it will be published as a publicly available open source research paper.[/p]

[p]This project will greatly improve the overarching organisational structure of the Index and more than double the number of distinct defined effects. It will incorporate a comprehensive literature review of other rudimentary altered state of consciousness ontologies, such as psychometric tools and informal classification systems found within books and online resources. We intend for this project to be fully open source so that it can become a ubiquitous resource analogous to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, providing a defined common lexicon so that researchers and laypeople alike can discuss altered states of consciousness in a succinct yet meaningful way.[/p]

[p]Thanks to my employers, the creation of this particular aspect of the project is already underway. However, new funding will be needed to integrate the improved SEI into the Effect Index website and empower the Subjective Effect Documentation community to continue improving the index in our ever-evolving world. This document details what we still need to bring Effect Index to its full potential as a global source of subjective effect knowledge and discovery.[/p]

[hr /]

[headered-textbox header="Web Development" subHeader="($28,053 - $30,000)" labelBackground="#AAAAAA" headerBackground="#F0F0F0"]
[p]My biggest priority for this project right now is improving the infrastructure behind our website. The existing website has evolved over time through the generous contributions of multiple community volunteers, but it is presently not able to accommodate any significant changes to the overall structure of the content. While we have an excellent starting point, there are a number of important features and improvements that will need to be implemented to turn this project into a platform capable of serving as a dedicated community resource for establishing, showcasing, and progressing the field of Subjective Effect Documentation.[/p]

[p]To maintain and implement improvements to the website, I would need to contract with a single freelance web developer, preferably on a long-term basis. My first choice for this role is a specific prominent community member who is highly capable, passionate about the project's goals, has an in-depth understanding of this project, is familiar with the website's backend code, and has been helping us work on it for a number of years.[/p]

[p]For in-depth details on each aspect of this, feel free to look at our spreadsheet [ext-link to="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HAqiUgjzsbaZVaSJRJLKkWJ40Rug3QmL13fTE02Cw-M/edit?usp=sharing"]here[/ext-link]. Otherwise, we have included a summarised list of our specific goals below.[/p]

[ul listStyle="circle"]
[li][i]User interface and profile improvements:[/i] Better, more customizable user profiles would facilitate writers, artists, replicators, and other people involved in our project to showcase their contributions and general online presence, therefore encouraging higher quality community contributions. We would like to implement:
[ul listStyle="square"]
[li]A way to change the order of replications on user pages so that they are better suited for use as portfolios.[/li]
[li]A way to better manage the categories of user pages, and the order of the users in them.[/li]
[li]Simplified trip report submission to our report index. Reports would then undergo moderation and manual approval before being integrated into the Subjective Effect Index via the effect tagging process.[/li]
[li]Upgrading the user interface to allow direct upload of images, videos, gifs, and audio files without resorting to an external FTP client. This would allow replicators and visionary artists to submit their own content easily to relevant effect pages and prevent changes in third-party services from disabling community assets.[/li]
[li]Upgrading the trip report editor to fix numerous issues to make writing trip reports easier, as well as making trip reports easier for machine learning to process and reliably analyze. These changes include the input fields needing to be more strict with the values they accept, as well as converting between units for the user. The medications list should also be a separate list of meds and dosages, similar to how the substances box works. A more consistent time format would help with readability and ML processing. The editor should also strip whitespace around input fields.[/li]
[li]A live preview for the VCode editor would be immensely helpful, especially for large content and formatting-dense articles.[/li]
[li]These changes would take an estimated 190 hours to add (~$5130 USD).[/li][/ul][/li]

[li][i]Structural improvements:[/i] To remain a relevant resource, the website should be upgraded to accommodate the following:
[ul listStyle="square"]
[li]The newest edition of the Subjective Effect Index is being developed under Josie Kins’ work with Mind State Design Labs, and we should have the website fully prepared for the new effects and general overarching structure of the ontology by the time it is published and available to the public.[/li]
[li]A directory of other Altered State of Consciousness Ontologies, with direct comparison to the Subjective Index. This will essentially be a user-facing showcase of the literature review that Josikinz is already working on with Mind State Design Labs.[/li]
[li]These changes would take an estimated 180 hours to add (~$4860 USD).[/li][/ul][/li]

[li]Ideally as many pages outside of effects, articles, etc, should be editable within the UI of the website to the maximum extent that is practically possible. This will take inspiration from the way in which MediaWiki allows people to do much the same thing.
[ul listStyle="square"]
[li]We’ll need to make embeddable vcode components for a wider array of site features: tabs, read more button, tabs for viewing multiple versions of an article or article section
allow creation / editing of arbitrary pages with vcode[/li]
[li]changing an article's icon in the web editor[/li]
[li]We need version control for articles, much like with MediaWiki. This would allow us to track edits and revert changes more easily. Something which is essential for giving people more editor privileges.
[li]These changes would take an estimated 160 hours to add (~$4320 USD).[/li][/li][/ul][/li]

[li]A function for redirecting effects to other effects or webpages, so you create an effect that essentially serves an alternative title which people may search for. (~10h / $270)[/li]
[li]Implement timestamps into the error log.[/li]
[li]Automatic citation generation in a set format would make managing citations easier, as well as preferring DOIs. (~20h / $540)[/li]
[li]Some things such as the “project” tab could have a scrolling TOC on the side? Discuss. (~30h / $810)[/li]
[li]The “About Us” button on the page only displays after hitting “read more”. Most people probably won’t click “read more”. This is a small thing but should absolutely be fixed.[/li]
[li]Implementing analytics to see what pages people interact with / how they interact with them (eg, what elements are clicked the most?) would be helpful when designing articles to see which elements convey information better, and so on. (~50h / $1350)[/li]
[li]A discord bot to post updates / help manage the EI (eg, when someone submits a new trip report).  (~20h / $540)[/li]
[li] The main page should be overhauled with new information and content, as well as phrasing such as “Hallucinogenic substance classes” being updated to use modern language. (~15h / $405)[/li]
[li]A way to search through all articles / vcode components for text, to aide in updating content and fixing references to broken components. (~30h / $810)[/li]
[li]Proper error handling and status codes from the API, instead of returning 500 for everything. (~30h / $810)[/li]
[li]Embeddable gif support in the image viewer. (~15h / $405)[/li]
[li]Articles that were published before the publish date system was added are missing a publish date. Adding a box to manually enter a date would be ideal. (~5h / $135)[/li]
[/ul]
[ul listStyle="circle"]
[li][i]Article and report editing improvements:[/i] We would like to implement various goals in order to make the creation and editing of content on the Effect Index easier and faster for editors.[/li]
[ul listStyle="square"]
[li]Article formatting templates, to make creating standardised articles easier. (~15h / $675)[/li]
[li]Fixing bugs and issues with the editor, such as visual issues with regards to account permissions. (~11h / $297)[/li]
[li]A live preview for the VCode editor, and showing the article side-by-side instead of a tabbed view would make editing formatting easier.[/li]
[li]A component for showing substance durations and dosages would be nice to have, when referencing a specific substance.[/li]
[li]Inline citation links would be great (similar to mediawiki). The current css for them should also be more aesthetically pleasing. Currently the citations are too big and with too much space around them. (~30h / $810)[/li]
[li]Overhaul the replication gallery. I would prefer to have not just the option for slideshows, but collections of tiled thumbnails for a more presentable showcasing. (~60h / $1620)[/li]
[li]Tickboxes for managing profile roles, and managing effect tags rather than freestanding boxes would make site management easier. (~11h / $297)[/li]
[/ul][/ul][/headered-textbox]
[hr /]

[p]Depending on the number of features we are implementing and at an hourly rate of $27, we estimate that this platform overhaul would cost $30,000 to fully implement. Furthermore, once implemented it would directly contribute to the Phenomenology, Practise, and Psychedelic Projects of the EPRC.[/p]

[p]This project is ethically driven as a means of maximizing harm reduction and empowering people to make informed choices, for the benefit of the global community. So if you're passionate about the field of psychedelic and general phenomenological research, the potential for formalized Subjective Effect Documentation as a legitimate field of study, and the need for a truly comprehensive, universally applicable map of substance and other practice-induced altered states of consciousness, then please consider donating to our fundraising campaign.[/p]

[p]Every little helps and will go directly to the cause, thank you in advance.[/p]

children.name: p
children: In fact, this "waiting room" feels distinctively different from the main bulk of the trip to such an extent that it has led many DMT users to speculate that it is potentially some sort of psychedelic loading screen, during which the upcoming trip is being generated and planned out by the subconscious mind.

children.name: p
children: After “taking off”, the person will usually transition into the most impressive stage of the experience. However, in certain cases the user may feel stuck within the waiting room, and may even experience hallucinatory

It's also important to note that although still relatively common in its occurrence, the waiting room is the least consistent stage of a DMT trip, and many users will never experience it at all, while simply finding that their DMT trips skip over it instead.

children.name: p
children: Once the waiting room stage is either finished or skipped over, the user will feel that they have broken through into what is commonly referred to as the "other side". It is here where an incredibly wide variety of potential hallucinatory content can manifest itself. However, this intensified stage will still usually follow somewhat consistent themes and archetypes that are reported by many people who experience the substance.

children.name: p
children: These themes generally consist of visiting a hallucinated alternate reality that is often said to feel "more real" than everyday life. In terms of their visual aesthetic, these hallucinatory spaces usually consist of incomprehensibly complex psychedelic

These entities may also convey a sense of urgency, as though attempting to demonstrate a multitude of incredible things during the short amount of time that they have before the effects of the drug wear off.

children.name: p
children: After 2 - 10 minutes of this experience, the DMT trip will begin to wear off while moving into its fourth and final stage.

children.name: p
children: The final stage concludes the trip, with either the sensation of being pulled progressively further away from the

which quickly fades. Similar to how the content of a dream is commonly forgotten upon waking up, detailed memories of DMT experiences also often rapidly deteriorate upon returning to baseline consciousness. This
can be counteracted by taking notes, recounting the trip to another person in detail, recording a narration of the experience on audio or video, or using other such method.

that can persist for up to half an hour in extreme cases. This afterglow typically feels like a warm fuzziness throughout the body, and often leaves behind a sense of cognitive
, well-being, and mental clarity which can last for hours, days, or even weeks after the trip.

children.name: p
children: However, it is worth noting that if the user has consumed a dosage that is not strong enough to reach stages two and three, then this experience of coming down will simply manifest as a progressive reduction of intensity without any of the aforementioned effects or details.

children: Now that I've covered my model of durational stages, I would like to cover a generalised intensity scale that can be applied to the DMT experience as a whole. This intensity scale breaks the subjective effects of DMT into six distinct levels based around dosage range and subjective intensity, in which each level typically contains an expanding list of effects that generally intensify relative to the dosage consumed.

parsed.name: p

children.name: p

This level can, therefore, be mostly ignored by directing one's focus towards other things such as tasks or the external environment.

children.name: p

. At higher doses, this geometry is significantly more likely to result in states of

children.name: p
children: It is also worth noting that the
induced by vaporized DMT is widely considered to be the most profoundly intricate and complex manifestation of this effect out of any and all psychedelic drugs. Compared to the

produced by ayahuasca, the geometry appears more synthetic and digital in material composition, it demonstrates colour schemes that are similar to those experienced on LSD, and has an organized geometric structure reminiscent of that produced by psilocybin.

children.name: p
children: At this level, spontaneous tactile sensations become pronounced and fully manifested. The

children.name: int-link
children: style variations of these bodily sensations

children.name: i
children: a constant duration, feelings of movement, gentle character, all-encompassing placement, and euphoric in pleasurability

. This sensation typically maintains a consistent presence that quickly rises with the onset and hits a limit once the peak has been reached. It is usually only moderate in its intensity, but is capable of becoming very powerful at higher doses and can sometimes persist for up to half an hour after the experience itself has ended.

children.name: p
children: During a distinct DMT experience, the general nature of the substance becomes well-defined enough that ignoring its effects is difficult. However, the user is still in control enough to be able to just about partake in normal behaviours, remain functional, and be able to communicate. Depending on the person's level of experience, the effects can be allowed dominate the user’s perception, or they may be ignored and made secondary to other chosen activities.

children.name: p
children: At most, a distinct DMT trip may result in a well-defined "take off" followed by an ill-defined version of the "waiting room", while entirely skipping over stage three.
